comments.commentBody:
You're not the only one:

“I hope we shall crush in its birth the aristocracy of our monied corporations which dare already to challenge our government to a trial by strength, and bid defiance to the laws of our country.” Thomas Jefferson

"All contributions by corporations to any political committee or for any political purpose should be forbidden by law." Theodore Roosevelt (1905)

"We can have democracy in this country, or we can have great wealth concentrated in the hands of a few, but we can't have both." Justice Louis Brandeis

We voters deserve to have candidates run on a level field. That means free TV air time and equal access to other media, for free.

After all, we own the airwaves, not the TV networks. And taking a half hour a day from the cable channels is a kind of tax.

It works in England and most other industrial countries.

Bad. It led him to give a trillion dollars of our tax money to the banks, who claimed there was a crisis when there wasn't. The only crisis was the one affecting their bonuses.

The banks had financed Obama's campaign, after he backed off of his promise to use only Federal election funding.

Go to YouTube and watch aoeBailout7 to see how it happened.

bill at realamerica.webs.com

This is the most important story I've read about the Florida primary, yet, for some reason, it didn't make the Times' "top ten" list.   SuperPAC spending will undoubtedly determine the outcome of both the primary and the general election.  Congratulations, Mr. Blow, on nailing it down early.

It's worse than that. A corrupt supreme court may give you the white house if the voters don't. (GWBush LOST in Florida and the Country in 2000 -- check on Google or Bing).

It's easy to like someone who does not have the job, Hillary Clinton would not have been much different despite what you may believe. The simple fact is a President must govern from the center, center left or right but the center nonetheless Hillary would have been not much different if she was going to run for reelection. I've been around and an activist in politics for forty years. Writing congressmen, Senators, Presidents the FBI and CIA. Government is not what people think, being President the only part of executive power that lays soley with the President is foreign affairs In that regard President Obama has repaired much of the damage done by the two digit IQ President before him. Remembering George W. Bush was led astray by the likes of Cheney, Rumsfeld, Wolfowitz and Pearl who three out of four were chicken hawks who defied Vietnam but were more than willing to send others to their death or maiming of them. Proven by the fact that Laura Bush in G.W. Bush's 6th year that Cheney had used him for his own profit, ie; Halliburtons winning of NO BID contracts for Iraq where Cheney was still recieving deferred income. Barak Obama and Hillary Clinton a far more similar than they are different when it comes to politics, how to win friends and influence people. But in the end even if Hillary had won, she might have only been treated marginally better than the racists who use innuendo in their attempt to make Barak Obama a one term President. Romney or Gingrich stand no chance

Be it Mitt Romney or Newt the shrew, President Obama's record in foreign policies speak for themselves. bin Laden is dead, along with scores of other al Qaeda leaders who posed real and present dangers to the United States and its citizens. True to his word we are effectively out of Iraq.The drawdawn will continue and accelerate in Afghanistan. The countries of Tunisa, Egypt, Libya and now Syria are all changing before our eyes not because of anything republican politics and policies have enabled over the last thirty years but by the inferred insurance they have that the world has their back as they fight for freedoms denied by tyrants for decades. Yes, President Obama can claim the credit for it, just as a republican would have done given the opportunity. With private sector hiring continuing now for over 23 straight months and a jobs outlook that still has yet to improve enough for what we usually referred to as full employment at 4-5% unemployed to be accomplished it is more than fair to claim now that not just the private sector alone can rescue us from our economic malaise.The days of conpicuious comsumption may be over for good, no one knows for sure, but to build a economy based on consumerism leaves the country open for hard times, especially when between 61-64 % of our economy is financial based, not manufacturing. Pres. Obama in both his SOTU and in his town hall meeting which I watched was clear, save jobs and attract foreign manufactures to our shores, we can win
we have 10000 dept of state employees and 5000 contractors in iraq to process visa applications?
to lee,  you didn't read your nyt.  part of un sanction is export of syrian oil.  btw most countries in the middle east have oil.

Then  what happens to the Middle East once they begin to REALLY run out of oil Jack?    Do you think they won't be battling for the last drops of their only valuable  commodity?  ,and besides the ancient tribesmen of the desert who else is equipped to live in a vast empty penniless  desert peacefully?  T

It truly does reflect your lack of critical thinking skill.

Jenna, assume you are a mother and head of a household with three children. One of your sons brings home two of his gang friends and demands you to get out the house and let him become head of the household.

You locked yourself, your daughter and your other son on the 2nd floor and refuse to come downstairs. Your son said why don't you step aside and go hole up somewhere and let him run the show? He has street cred and new ways of thinking and so on and so forth.

You know he is going to kill your other son and your daughter will be raped if you let go of that baseball bat. Are you going to give up?

The rebel are just a tiny group of people backed by foreign power. Assad's supporters will be killed if the rebel comes to power.

(BTW, if you want to see a real revolution, check out the French, Russian, Chinese and Cuban revolution. A true revolution backed by the people is unstoppable and if this one in Syria is real, it would have ended months ago with just the will of Syrians)
I am astonished with all those who always claims that the middle east people can not be democratic. Those people always forget what the old Eastern country used to be.

No! It is NOT going to be the repeat of Libya where the US and its NATO puppets became the air force of a bunch of thugs they created and paid for.  It seems like Russia learned its lesson for not vetoing the UN resolution that the criminals in the west used to bomb schools and hospitals killing innocent men, women and children in Libya.
You think the corporate media, Washington mouthpieces, will do that?

@Sparky

You’d better come visit so we can clear up your delusions about public employees. It always amazes me (and the other one million who signed the petition) that people berate unionized workers for having decent wages and benefits, instead of organizing for the same for themselves.

I am not a public employee, but I’ve never resented their benefits--just wish the rest of us could get organized and demand the same. There’s really nothing “Cadillac” about public employees pay or benefits--it’s that many of the rest of us in the 99% are driving Yugos. That doesn’t make me jealous--it makes me angry about the policies that have undermined wages, benefits and organized labor for the last 30 years.

“To desecrate the cadaver or the memory of Bin Laden is to revive him. To cry one’s joy in the streets of our cities is to ape the turbaned barbarians who danced the night of Sept. 11. It is to tell them the ghastly competition continues between them and us.”'

One of the things that truly impressed me about the Obama Administration was how well they handled the death of Bin Laden. They did not desecrate the cadaver, or mutilate him, or expose him, as the ancient Greeks might have done. They showed no photos, tried to find him a burial in his native land, and ensured that his body was laid to rest before the 24 hour limit set by Muslim law. Look at the faces of those in the room, and you don't see joy or pleasure, but a mixture of anxiety and determination. No-one looks happy to be ordering the death of Bin Laden, but they're doing it anyway, because that is what their job requires. You might disagree with that way of doing the job, but it is clear that Obama, Biden, Clinton, Panetta and the rest thought long and hard about this.

I was under the impression that we had not "desecrated" the corpse at all.

Indeed, I thought I read that the body was afforded full Islamic rites. Perhaps burial at sea is not preferred, but not creating a memorial site was probably the wisest move.

It may not play in Paris, or Prague, but I think there's no question that killiing the man who attacked and killed thousands of Americans is more moral that declaring war on whatever country he was hiding out in, and killing thousands of inocent civilians.

I find it interesting that Vice President Biden advised against this strike against Bin Laden. To me, as a native born American, I have often been amazed at the praise which seems to come for those who act decisively, as Biden said of Obama 'this guy’s got a backbone like a ramrod'. Yet in the end, some decisions made and actions taken seem only to provoke, not make us safer or get us closer to the goal of peace.

I read tonight about Europeans' reaction to the killing of Bid Laden at the time. One quote from an article of May 5, 2011 in the New York Times stood out for me:

'Even the editor of the centrist weekly L’Express, Christophe Barbier, cautioned, “To victory one must not add provocation.” He added: “To desecrate the cadaver or the memory of Bin Laden is to revive him. To cry one’s joy in the streets of our cities is to ape the turbaned barbarians who danced the night of Sept. 11. It is to tell them the ghastly competition continues between them and us.”'

Though a sense of vindication rippled across our nation on that day, I wonder what the future brings in future retaliation from present or future generations of peoples of Arab nations, where we seem to tread with presumed impunity. Typically, revenge and retribution are not one way streets.
Where do we get “revenue” if not from taxes?
Spoken like a true fan.
So long as they give it their all, I'm with them all the way.

"Obama doesn't have TO speak."

Editing, grrrrrr.

Great principle but our politician have to sell themselves. Or let their surrogates to do it for them.

That's the reality.

Agreed. And remember the deft, efficient way the president dealt with Donald Trump. No confrontation, no soaring rhetoric, merely a gentle pinprick during the White House press corps dinner that left the Donald fuming, deflated and utterly defenseless. As in jiu jitsu, one doesn't have to be the toughest or strongest to come out on top.

The REAL guys don't talk, much less brag about the things they do.

The REAL guys let their actions speak, instead.

Obama doesn't have speak.

Ms. Olsen

The separation of the church and state clause has no exceptions as far as being not for profit, paying non taxes etc. These Organized Religions are all in the God business as are the TV evangelicals and these monster medical centers of the Catholic and Methodist verity.

Stu, the system of vetoes was adopted for a good reason: it was to minimize a number of wars of choice by major nations. Dismount it and next second you will find youself in a middle of a spreading spiral of endless bombings of everything that can`t by everybody who can.

David:

It is the George Orwell's "Animal Farm" democracy: "All animals are equal, but some animals are more equal than other."
What about Bahrain? Whose going to tell the Saudis their dictatorship there should end?

Once again it becomes clear that the only way to accomplish anything of importance at the U.N. is to have the permanent members of the Security Council relinquish their precious veto power.  The Cold War has ended and the world is no longer divided between the totalitarian East and the democratic West.  The U.S. wields its veto these days only for the sake of Israeli settlements while Russia and China allow people like Bashir-the-Butcher-Son-of-a-Butcher continue to massacre his own citizens.  It's time to let Tel Aviv, Damascus, Tehran, Pyongyang and the rest stand on their own two feet without protection from their friends on the Council.  Let the majority rule at the U.N. and, ultimately, all the dictators will have to stand down.

Paul, If Obama is a 'failed President' as you Republicans are fond of saying, any Republican nominee should be able to beat him right? Why are Republicans so obsessed with finding the 'one that has a chance of defeating Obama'? If Newt can beat Obama, he is your man, never mind the serious contradictions with the supposed moral value of the party. If Romney can beat Obama, then he is your man, never mind that he cannot hold one position consistently.

BTW, have you seen the recent Rasmussen polls on how Obama fares against likely Republican nominees?

You've almost got it. Real close. Just a minor point.

He looks "like the guy who fired" you from your job and hired me instead.

Andy writes:

"There are only 1.5m Republicans in Florida?"

I suspect I'm not alone in missing your point, Andy.

Without question, Florida is the single most important state in a presidential election. Is there any question which party New York will support? How about Texas?

But how about Florida, Andy -- not so clear?
There are only 1.5m Republicans in Florida?

I cannot for the life of me understand how Obama can be described as a liberal.   The health care reform plan is slightly more conservative version of the Dole-Kemp GOP health care plan of 1994.   While liberals were hoping to wind down the wars in Afghanistan and Iraq, Obama instead cranked up the war in Afghanistan with a 'surge'.    Obama has stuck to the Bush timetable for withdrawing troops from Iraq.   It seems to me he has done all the things a GOP president would do.

Really?  I couldn't wait for his term to end in Mass.  He lied to us to get into office when in fact he was just using the governorship to springboard his national presidential aspirations.  He traveled the country while governor disparaging the State of Massachusetts while he was in office.  He is a despicable liar and will say and do anything to get elected.  All you republicans: you are right to fear him.  Find another candidate.
Governor Romney is the first credible candidate in a very long time.  His demonstrated successes in both the public and private sectors will ensure his entry into the Presidency.
